Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on gender and clan membership; RAD failed to consider the National Documentation Package (NDP) despite recognizing Somali citizenship law.
Procedural_Issue: RAD refused to consider all evidence, specifically the NDP; failure to independently assess country condition documents.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider the NDP, which contains critical country condition evidence.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues cited as basis for rejection by RPD and upheld by RAD.
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected claims; RAD upheld decision.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to RAD for reconsideration by a different panel.
Remedy_Sought: Re-evaluation of refugee claim with full consideration of evidence
Decision_Rationale: RAD must independently assess all evidence, including country condition documents, rather than merely applying a reasonableness standard. Omission of NDP prevented proper assessment.

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection, which was denied by the RPD and upheld by the RAD using a reasonableness standard.
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent review
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status; RAD initially upheld the decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; RAD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Legal challenge to RAD's application of reasonableness standard
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by RAD under correct standard of review
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness vs. correctness debate; court suggests broader interpretation needed
Decision_Rationale: RAD should conduct a more comprehensive review in line with Court jurisprudence

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed forced marriage and domestic violence as basis for asylum
Procedural_Issue: RAD's standard of review on RPD's credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: RPD rejected claim due to credibility concerns; RAD upheld the finding
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility assessment
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RAD's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: RAD must conduct independent analysis unless RPD's credibility finding is reasonable
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by RAD to RPD's credibility finding
Decision_Rationale: RAD's analysis was sufficient and within acceptable legal bounds
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court

Application_Facts: The Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed by the RPD and upheld by the RAD, prompting a judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD erred by applying a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent assessment.
Decision_Outcome: RAD decision quashed
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred back to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Independent reassessment by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: The RAD has equal expertise to the RPD in assessing documentary evidence and must conduct an independent assessment rather than reviewing for reasonableness.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose previous visa applications
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants omitted prior visa applications; claimed misunderstanding as explanation
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of previous visa applications affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer did not confront applicants with employment inconsistencies
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Prior visa application records, employment history statements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborative evidence supporting explanation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative inference drawn due to omissions and inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application rejected based on credibility concerns
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded lack of credibility due to unexplained omissions and inconsistent employment history

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer erred in assessing credibility and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported employment history, visa application forms
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inconsistencies in employment history and failure to provide supporting evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of corroborative evidence despite opportunity
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Totality of circumstances in credibility evaluation
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; officer considered all provided information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Corroborative evidence not required but may be considered
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of conflicting statements in temporary and permanent residence applications
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not alleged; issue centered on credibility and inconsistency

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and procedural fairness in immigration assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to confront applicant with inconsistencies during interview
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in employment details undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment information from multiple visa applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Differing employment histories in successive applications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicants provided conflicting information without explanation or corroboration
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credibility assessed based on internal consistency and plausibility
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No breach found; applicants were aware of their submissions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness does not require explicit confrontation if information was self-disclosed
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior temporary resident visa application contained different employment data
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not established; discrepancies arose from self-reporting inconsistencies

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on ethnic persecution in Hungary; evidence of systemic discrimination and violence against Romany citizens
Claimant_Status: Romany citizens from Hungary seeking refugee protection
Procedural_Issue: Flawed credibility assessment by RPD
Insufficient analysis in decision-making
Evidence_Used: Evidence of systemic discrimination and violence against Romany people in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to adequately analyze available evidence on state protection
Credibility_Assessment: RPD's credibility assessment was flawed and unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD initially rejected refugee claim based on adequate state protection in Hungary
Outcome: RPD's decision set aside as unreasonable
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Redetermination of claim by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Lack of state protection must be proven with clear evidence
Decision_Rationale: Hungary does not provide adequate state protection despite RPD findings; decision lacked sufficient reasoning and proper credibility analysis

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada since age three, has Canadian spouse and child, no recent criminal activity
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-status individual with pending humanitarian and compassionate application

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Adult offender with prior criminal record
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Rehabilitation, family ties in Canada, no imminent danger to public

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Adult offender with history of reformation
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Long-term residence in Canada since childhood, marriage to Canadian citizen, parental responsibilities

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant has Canadian-born child, no further charges since past convictions, pending humanitarian application

Application_Facts: Applicant fled Haiti in 1991, lived illegally in the US for 15 years without seeking asylum, entered Canada and applied for refugee status in 2006, claimed persecution due to Lavalas party involvement
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration laws in the US and Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under IRPA section 72 challenging the Board’s denial of refugee status
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting Lavalas party involvement
Failure to explain delay in seeking asylum
Credibility_Assessment: Assessed as lacking credibility due to prolonged stay in the US without seeking protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Board
Judicial review dismissed
Outcome: Application for refugee status rejected
Court upheld Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Particularized risk on a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: Fear based on generalized violence in Haiti does not meet Convention grounds
No evidence of individualized risk
Credibility undermined by failure to seek asylum during 15-year US residence

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed new evidence (Di Capua as the informant) but failed to call Di Capua as a witness during trials.
Procedural_Issue: Courts previously ruled on the informant's identity relevance.
No tangible proof showed prosecutorial abuse.
Evidence_Used: Claim that Di Capua was the informant
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failed to call Di Capua as a witness
Lack of tangible proof of prosecutorial abuse
Decision_Outcome: Mr. Lamontagne's decision was reasonable
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Ministerial decision
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, considering mixed questions of law and fact
Decision_Rationale: The applicant’s claim was previously considered; no new significant evidence or procedural abuse shown.
Authority_Responsible: Mr. Lamontagne, Minister under Criminal Code s. 696.3

Dispute_Type: Miscarriage of justice claim based on coercion
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Minister's decision rejecting miscarriage of justice application
Evidence_Assessment: Claim that Di Capua forced applicant to transport heroin
Attorney General's discretion in staying proceedings against Di Capua
Decision_Outcome: Minister's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show new significant evidence and miscarriage of justice
Credibility_Factor: Repeated litigation of Di Capua's role without new evidence
Legal_Rule: Minister may review for miscarriage of justice if new significant evidence exists
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, unless flagrant violation of justice or abuse of procedure
Legal_Framework: Criminal Code provisions on judicial review and miscarriage of justice
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Criminal Code s. 696.3
Authority: Mr. Lamontagne, Minister responsible for reviewing miscarriage of justice applications

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration violation under paragraph 27(2)(h) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Removal in conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was removed despite a court order requiring his presence for a criminal hearing.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Removal executed without regard to conflicting judicial order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal violated s. 50(1) as it conflicted with a judicial order requiring the applicant’s presence.

Crimes.Violation_Type: Execution of removal order conflicting with judicial requirement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant removed despite court order requiring attendance at criminal proceeding; later returned voluntarily.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with s. 50(1) before removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Judicial order mandating presence for criminal hearing
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Declaration addressing consequences of unlawful removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Compliance with s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal contravened statutory prohibition under s. 50(1); declaration warranted despite voluntary return.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Lawfulness of removal during pending criminal proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Removal without ensuring compliance with judicial requirements
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Violation of s. 50(1) due to conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to ensure presence required by court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Wong remained in Canada after a removal order was issued; requested deferral due to risk upon return.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess risk before refusing deferral
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, allegations of risk in China
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not consider risk evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal pending PRRA assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by not considering potential risk upon return

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer must assess risk despite subsequent PRRA status
Crimes.Evidence_Type: PRRA application, personal claims of risk
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution/torture upon return to China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timeliness and consideration of risk allegations
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal based on PRRA being subsequent without risk assessment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Must consider risk if no timely PRRA conducted
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Allegations of personal risk in country of origin

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a narcotic for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Wong had criminal conviction affecting admissibility; sought deferral of removal citing risk and family ties.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Inadmissible permanent resident due to criminality
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to criminal record and illegal re-entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of risk assessment prior to removal decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal record, PRRA application, family circumstances
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to evaluate risk despite outstanding PRRA
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending risk assessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of removal deferral based on risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to consider potential risk upon return despite duty to do so

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to criminal history involving prohibited items
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Risk of harm or danger upon return or continued presence
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of serious criminal conduct including weapons offenses
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Possession of prohibited weapons indicating potential danger
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to connect criminal history with current risk assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; based on official documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections relating to security grounds and risk assessment
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal deferral based on humanitarian and protection concerns
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Potential exposure to persecution or torture if removed

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Canadian jurisprudence on standard of review and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Gavryushenko claimed fear of persecution in Russia due to political opposition to the Chechen war and threats from fascist groups; he passed through the U.S. without seeking asylum there
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian entry requirements; applied for refugee status upon arrival
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of persecution claims by the Refugee Division, despite noted candour
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and unambiguous reasons for credibility findings
Inadequate consideration of post-arrival evidence
Evidence_Used: Circumstances of travel through the U.S.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal ignored relevant evidence submitted after arrival
Misinterpreted failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Credibility_Assessment: Mixed: praised candour but ultimately found allegations fabricated without clear justification
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected by Refugee Division
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Decision quashed
Referred back for rehearing before a new panel
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the Refugee Division’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Rehearing of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The Federal Court found the Refugee Division’s reasoning unclear and internally inconsistent, particularly regarding credibility, and failing to properly address key evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada for serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tran received a 12-month conditional sentence for marijuana production; maximum penalty was 7 years, later increased to 14 years; no actual imprisonment imposed
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to inadmissibility review as a permanent resident
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: CBSA officer's decision subject to judicial review on reasonableness grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conditional sentence length, nature of offense, statutory maximum penalty
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to recognize that conditional sentences do not constitute 'imprisonment' under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conditional sentence not equivalent to imprisonment; sentence did not exceed 6 months in custody; offense not punishable by 10+ years at time of conviction

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Conditional sentence imposed; targeted non-serious offenders
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate (maximum penalty 7 years at time of offense)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low risk based on sentencing outcome
Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety risk related to drug offenses
Crimes.Threat_Source: Individual involvement in illegal drug production
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Official court records accepted as credible
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Whether a 12-month conditional sentence constitutes imprisonment under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act; IRPA s 36(1)(a)

Application_Facts: Ms. Hong provided evidence of her ties to Vietnam and financial support but failed to fully document her employment and financial capacity. The Visa Officer found her proposed studies unreasonable and insufficiently funded.
Procedural_Issue: Ms. Hong filed for judicial review after her visa denial.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of ties to Vietnam, financial support documents
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation of employment and financial capacity
Credibility_Assessment: Proposed studies deemed unreasonable; intent to return questioned
Decision_Outcome: Visa denied
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Grant of student visa, overturning of refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to demonstrate sufficient financial resources and intent to leave Canada after studies
Decision_Rationale: The Visa Officer reasonably concluded that Ms. Hong did not sufficiently demonstrate financial sufficiency or strong intent to return to Vietnam after her studies.

Application_Facts: Claimants employed Palestinian Arabs in Israel; daughters refused military service on grounds of conscientious objection
Procedural_Issue: IRB allegedly ignored key evidence regarding state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of attacks by Jewish extremists
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient proof supporting daughters' conscientious objection claims
Credibility_Assessment: IRB found insufficient credibility or proof regarding conscientious objection claims
Decision_Outcome: Decision on state protection set aside and referred back; conscientious objection claims dismissed
Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration on state protection; daughters' claims dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees based on persecution and conscientious objection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IRB decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness simpliciter for mixed law/fact questions
Decision_Rationale: IRB failed to consider key evidence on state protection; insufficient evidence on conscientious objection

Application_Facts: Board had only four members instead of five; allowed CEO and DRO representations at initial stage
Procedural_Issue: Lack of quorum (only four members); lack of opportunity for rebuttal
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed without hearing
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted to properly constituted Board
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside dismissal and rehearing by valid Board
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review)
Decision_Rationale: Failure to meet statutory quorum and procedural fairness requirements

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to abuse by his father; RPD denied claim citing Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Tirana; RAD upheld RPD decision without addressing evidence of undue hardship in Tirana
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to address relevant evidence regarding personal circumstances affecting IFA
Evidence_Used: Evidence of family abuse, personal circumstances, and conditions in Tirana
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RAD did not consider evidence suggesting undue hardship in Tirana
Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; focus was on IFA analysis
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on IFA; RAD upheld decision
Outcome: Judicial review granted
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD's failure to address key evidence rendered its IFA analysis unreasonable

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency obligation appeal with humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board committed an error of law or made a patently unreasonable finding of fact
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant faced credibility issues due to inconsistent explanations, employment records, and financial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28 - Residency obligations (730 days in 5 years)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Patently unreasonable finding by ignoring relevant evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly harsh assessment and dismissal of credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Permanent resident must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days in any five-year period
Crimes.Application_Factor: Conflicting evidence on residency and lifestyle as a loan shark
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a different Board member

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided conflicting evidence about presence in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in travel records, employment, and finances
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Immigration Appeal Division under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Overlooked bank statements and veterinary visits
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies in documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different Board member
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored relevant evidence and focused improperly on applicant's profession

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency determination with suspicion of financial misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board’s factual findings on residency
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting travel, employment, and financial evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Must be physically present in Canada for 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable rejection of evidence and credibility findings
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 28
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Provided documentation to support residency claims

Crimes.Violation_Type: Improper consideration of irrelevant factors in residency assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant engaged in loan sharking; Board used this to dismiss residency evidence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Disputed due to credibility and evidentiary issues
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper reliance on irrelevant conduct (loan sharking)
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board’s authority under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Relevant evidence dismissed due to applicant's profession
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively impacted by association with loan sharking, though unrelated to residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored credible evidence solely because of applicant's occupation

Application_Facts: The applicants' claim was denied due to credibility issues.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD improperly applied a judicial review standard instead of conducting a proper appeal.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues led to denial of the refugee claim.
Decision_Outcome: RPD's denial of refugee status upheld by RAD initially, then set aside on judicial review.
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded to RAD for redetermination.
Relief_Sought: Challenge to the legality of the RAD decision upholding the RPD's denial.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the case by the RAD under correct legal standards.
Standard_of_Review: The RAD must conduct an appeal, not a judicial review, applying the correct legal standards.
Decision_Rationale: The RAD failed to conduct a proper appeal and incorrectly applied a judicial review standard.

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee definition under IRPA
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Refugee Status Provisions
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed past persecution in Mauritania based on ethnicity and imputed political opinion; Board found discrimination but not persecution; country conditions have changed, reducing future risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the Refugee Protection Division's rejection of refugee claim
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of country conditions in Mauritania, applicants' testimony, evidence of ethnic discrimination
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish persecution as opposed to discrimination
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation and reasonableness of decision
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Fear of persecution on enumerated grounds under IRPA; changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Board reasonably concluded that while there was evidence of discrimination, it did not amount to persecution; changed circumstances in Mauritania mitigate future risk; no compelling reasons to override country condition changes
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether illegal work and residence can be considered in denying humanitarian and compassionate relief
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, immigration status history, refugee claim outcome
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Illegal employment and residence after refugee claim denial
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Discretionary evaluation of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Self-sufficiency achieved through illegal means not a positive factor
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation related to immigration status and employment authorization

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether unauthorized work is a relevant consideration in humanitarian applications
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Continued unauthorized work despite notice to cease
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Work history, immigration status documentation, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on adaptation and family
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Unauthorized employment as a negative factor
Crimes.Application_Error: No error in considering unauthorized work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of legal self-sufficiency despite integration efforts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not applicable directly, but linked to false representation of status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remained in Canada after loss of status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 114(2) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claim denial and worked illegally
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants without valid immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Continued presence and work without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application assessed under H&C provisions despite lack of status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Officer had authority to assess H&C application despite unlawful stay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of stay, family connections, employment history, financial independence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate unusual hardship or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative inference from continued illegal presence and work
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application refused; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Applicants required to leave Canada or reapply from abroad
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary fairness and reasonableness under H&C framework
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Illegal actions cannot form the basis of a successful humanitarian claim

Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err in assessing the applicant's credibility and disregarding psychological evidence?
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Officer's decision upheld
Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistencies and implausibilities in the applicant's testimony
Evidence_Type: Psychological reports acknowledged but not deemed sufficient to override credibility concerns
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant claimed refugee protection due to alleged persecution risks in their home state
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility concerns based on inconsistent testimony
Application_Error: Alleged misinterpretation or disregard of psychological evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Psychological evidence not ignored but given limited weight
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of credibility
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board / Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and claimed refugee protection due to alleged risks upon return
Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with residency conditions by overstaying visa
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility undermined by inconsistencies and demeanor
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following PRRA rejection
Evidence_Used: Psychological reports relying on applicant’s testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Expert reports considered unreliable due to dependence on non-credible testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible based on inconsistencies and demeanor
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Outcome: Officer's decision upheld by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Refugee protection and stay in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings adequately justified; decision transparent and intelligible

Application_Facts: Ms. Ryan was absent for 1,136 days during the four-year period preceding her application, resulting in only 324 days of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No – only 324 days of residence, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied a qualitative test instead of strictly assessing physical presence
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada, illness-related reasons for absence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or justification to offset prolonged absence under statutory requirements
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation rather than credibility
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship approval by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Overturned on appeal
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside the decision and denying citizenship based on non-compliance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' as physical presence with limited exceptions
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's interpretation fell outside acceptable outcomes by allowing qualitative factors to override clear statutory residency requirements

Application_Facts: Applicant resided in Canada for 1403 days during the reference period
Residency_Compliance: Sufficient physical presence (1403 days), but lack of detailed documentation
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to clearly state the residency test applied and did not analyze relevant factors from Koo (Re)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed documentation supporting residency
Credibility_Assessment: Judge approved application based on credibility
Decision_Outcome: Approval of citizenship application
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Appeal to Federal Court, reassessment by different Citizenship Judge
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity on the test applied and inadequate justification

Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada illegally and sought refugee protection.
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to conduct independent analysis and overly deferred to RPD.
Evidence_Used: RPD's credibility findings based on applicant's testimony and documentation.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation or corroboration supporting entry claims.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible; RAD deferred without independent assessment.
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by both RPD and RAD.
Outcome: Judicial review granted, RAD decision set aside.
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different RAD panel member
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard required, but RAD applied excessive deference.
Decision_Rationale: RAD’s decision was unreasonable due to lack of independent analysis.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements in an immigration context
Legal_Issue: Improper application of standard of review by RAD
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for new determination.
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed not credible by RPD and RAD regarding religious persecution claim.
Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence related to religious persecution
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to refugee eligibility and credibility assessment
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony and lack of supporting evidence
Application_Error: RAD used judicial review language instead of conducting independent re-evaluation.
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring independent analysis by RAD
Evidence_Ignored: Potential inconsistencies not independently assessed by RAD
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard for factual and mixed fact-law issues
Application_Factor: RAD must reassess evidence, not merely review RPD decision
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD’s negative decision based on credibility
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard; error due to excessive deference

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving allegations of misrepresentation
Legal_Issue: Excessive deference by RAD to RPD on credibility and documentation expectations
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for re-determination
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s religious identity and persecution claim found inconsistent and not credible
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, documents related to religious practice and persecution in Turkey
Legal_Provision: Section 40(1) of IRPA – Misrepresentation
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent evidence and unreasonable documentation demands accepted without scrutiny
Application_Error: RAD failed to independently analyze evidence and upheld RPD decision with flawed reasoning
Assessment_Standard: Independent reasonableness assessment required by RAD
Evidence_Ignored: Lack of proper justification for discrediting applicant despite some corroborative evidence
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard with duty to independently assess facts
Application_Factor: RAD must not rely solely on RPD’s conclusions without re-evaluation
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed by RPD and upheld by RAD
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard improperly applied through excessive deference
Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies in submitted documents supporting religious identity

Crime_Name: Costs Assessment in Intellectual Property Litigation
Legal_Issue: Assessment of costs under Column IV vs. Column III of Tariff B
Procedural_Stage: Trial, Post-trial motion for cost assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Complexity of legal issues, business significance, conduct during litigation, settlement offer timing
Decision_Outcome: Costs assessed under Column III, double costs awarded after settlement offer date
Burden_of_Proof: Plasticair to justify higher cost column based on complexity and importance
Credibility_Factor: Delays caused by Plasticair weighed against their claim for higher costs
Legal_Rule: Costs discretion under Federal Court Rules considering result, complexity, settlement offers, and conduct
Grounds_for_Claim: High stakes, technical complexity, importance of case
Outcome_on_Merits: Both claims dismissed, but costs awarded to Plasticair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of legal issues, duration of trial, expert and travel expenses, settlement offer timeline
Legal_Framework: Tariff B of the Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: M.K. Plastics defended against infringement and asserted invalidity
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, procedural history
Remedy_Requested: Costs under Column IV of Tariff B
Outcome: Costs awarded under Column III, double costs post-settlement offer, reasonable expenses approved
Legal_Provision: Federal Court Rules, SOR/98-106, Tariff B

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim found not credible due to vague evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Anecdotal and uncorroborated claims about police involvement
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of torture by Georgian police official over unpaid debt
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence linking individual to state actors
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence supporting risk claim
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard with deference to officer expertise
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passport at entry

Crimes.Crime_Name: False documents for the purpose of gaining entry
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA Officer's assessment of risk claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of persecution lacked evidentiary support
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Unsubstantiated allegations of threats from criminal with police links
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm due to use of false documents and alleged connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No proof of state involvement or lack of protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient evidence to establish personal risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent travel document upon entry
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of false passport for entry into Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to make a refugee claim prior to removal order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural non-compliance in refugee claim process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to timely refugee claims
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered with false documents and delayed claiming refugee status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Prior use of false passport affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to file refugee claim before removal order issued
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA submission and background country information
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence on state inability to protect
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk claims
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Georgia capable of providing protection; no nexus to state persecution

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether private debt dispute constitutes grounds for protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Vague and uncorroborated claims about police-linked creditor
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personal risk and state complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation or third-party verification
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Private disputes not equivalent to persecution without state involvement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged threats from individual allegedly connected to police
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to insufficient evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of debt, alleged ties to law enforcement, availability of state protection

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in upholding the RPD's credibility findings
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law regarding reasonableness and deference
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant lacked credibility due to insufficient detail in describing speeches; RAD upheld this finding
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of IRPA (RAD review authority)
Section 101(1)(a) of IRPA (refugee protection basis)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Level of detail provided in describing political speeches
Application_Error: RAD failed to identify that RPD's credibility assessment was unreasonable and not evidence-based
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness, intelligibility, and justification of credibility findings
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's detailed descriptions of speeches as recorded in transcript
Application_Factor: Consistency and specificity of applicant's narrative
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination by a reasonable fact-based decision

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 49(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Application_Facts: Husband breached curfew, triggering bond forfeiture consideration
Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider partial forfeiture despite discretion under s. 49(4)
Decision_Outcome: Officer erred in law
Outcome: Decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider partial forfeiture constitutes legal error

Crimes.Crime_Name: Forfeiture of performance bond under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Whether Officer erred in enforcing full $80,000 bond without considering partial forfeiture
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 49(4)
Evidence_Assessment: Testimony on Officer's discretion and interpretation
Decision_Outcome: Officer erred in law
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show legal error
Legal_Rule: s. 49(4) allows partial forfeiture at Officer's discretion
Key_Evidence_Considered: Testimony regarding Officer's understanding of discretion
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remitted
Legal_Provision: s. 49(4) IRPR

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff can amend its statement of claim to include newly registered copyrights without causing injustice to the defendant
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit evidence was reviewed; registrations create presumptions but do not impose significant additional burden
Decision_Outcome: Application to amend the statement of claim was granted
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must demonstrate that amendment does not cause injustice
Credibility_Factor: Timing of copyright registration and discovery of infringement in January 1986
Legal_Rule: Amendments are allowed under Rule 420 if expedient for resolving disputes and do not result in injustice
Standard_of_Review: Whether the amendment would cause injustice that is not compensable by costs
Grounds_for_Claim: Discovery of copyright infringement after commencement of action
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; procedural decision on amendment only
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit, timing of copyright registration, alignment of new claims with existing issues
Legal_Framework: Copyright law and civil procedure rules
Defendant_Response: Potential prejudice from late amendment, though not substantiated as causing injustice
Remedy_Requested: Leave to amend statement of claim to include newly registered copyrights
Outcome: Amendment permitted
Legal_Provision: Rule 420
Authority: Court applying procedural rules to civil litigation

Legal_Issue: Credibility of applicant's claim of political persecution
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Board doubted political activity post-1994 and political motive of 2002 incident due to omissions in police reports and immigration interviews
Legal_Provision: Definition of Convention refugee under IRPA: well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged political persecution in Sri Lanka following their party's election loss
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of the applicant's testimony and consistency of statements
Application_Error: Failure to properly assess credibility based on inconsistent reasoning
Evidence_Ignored: Potential explanations for omissions in prior statements
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard of review applied by court
Application_Factor: Timing and plausibility of political involvement after 1994
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different Board member for reassessment
Authority: Canadian immigration law, IRPA, Convention refugee definition

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal past, including impersonating a police officer. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body deemed her a potential risk to civil aviation based on I.4(d) of the Program.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness due to the tribunal's expertise and legislative purpose.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal past involving impersonating a police officer
Risk assessment under I.4(d) of the Program
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: I.4(d) of the Program
section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's transportation security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000. Despite providing additional information and obtaining a conditional discharge, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of the legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the applicant's challenge, upholding the cancellation of her security clearance.
Defendant_Response: Provided additional information and obtained a conditional discharge
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000 and was given a conditional discharge. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision is not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review is dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Cancellation of the applicant's transportation security clearance due to her criminal history and perceived risk to civil aviation.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application for judicial review, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Legal_Framework: Dr Q v. College of Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the arbitration clause in the Booking Note requires a stay of proceedings under section 50 of the Federal Courts Act
Governing_Law: Article 8 of the Commercial Arbitration Code
section 50 of the Federal Courts Act
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed
proceedings stayed in favor of arbitration
Legal_Rule: Courts must refer parties to arbitration if there is a valid arbitration agreement, unless it is null or incapable of being performed (Article 8)
Grounds_for_Claim: Existence and enforceability of arbitration clause in Booking Note
Outcome_on_Merits: Dispute must proceed through arbitration as per Booking Note terms
Defendant_Response: Motion for stay of proceedings based on arbitration agreement
Remedy_Requested: Stay of proceedings in favor of arbitration
Outcome: Action stayed; arbitration mandated
Legal_Provision: Article 8 of the Commercial Arbitration Code
section 50 of the Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant suspected of PKK membership based on undisclosed evidence; requested disclosure but received no response.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to inadmissibility concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of meaningful disclosure of grounds and evidence prior to interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose key evidence affecting decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant denied fair opportunity to respond to allegations due to non-disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Procedural fairness breach in immigration process
Crimes.Violation_Type: Breach of procedural fairness in assessing inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Pusat not informed of specific reasons for suspicion of PKK membership despite repeated requests; no post-interview submission allowed
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Mr. Pusat, applicant for permanent residency
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose grounds and evidence, denial of opportunity to respond
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Denial of procedural fairness undermined legitimacy of decision-making process

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Suspected membership in PKK, a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reasonable grounds to believe applicant was a member of PKK
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence not disclosed; credibility could not be assessed by applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unable to assess due to lack of disclosure

Dispute_Type: Trademark infringement and expungement of trademark
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's trademark 'Home Sentinel & Design' is confusingly similar to the plaintiff's trademarks under s. 20 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Witness testimonies, market differences, appearance and usage context of marks
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed; defendant's trademark allowed to coexist with plaintiff's trademarks
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's trademarks considered weak due to common use of 'sentinel'
Legal_Rule: Confusion is determined by the likelihood that the public would infer both marks are associated with the same entity, assessed using factors in s. 6(5) of the Trade-marks Act
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under statutory framework
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement due to similarity between 'Home Sentinel & Design' and plaintiff's 'Sentinel'-related marks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Common use of 'sentinel', target consumer differences (cost-conscious DIY vs. high-end services), visual and contextual differences in mark usage
Legal_Framework: Statutory analysis under the Trade-marks Act focusing on confusion
Defendant_Response: Mark not confusingly similar; different market positioning and appearance
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, market analysis, comparative mark evaluation
Outcome: Claim dismissed; no relief granted to plaintiff
Legal_Provision: s. 20 of the Trade-marks Act (infringement), s. 6(5) (confusion factors)

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board correctly applied the legal test for state protection
Governing_Law: Requirement of 'adequate protection' by the state, not merely 'serious efforts'
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of safety in Walvis Bay and availability of internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected based on internal flight alternative
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to demonstrate lack of adequate state protection
Legal_Rule: States must provide 'adequate protection' to citizens
Standard_of_Review: Correctness or reasonableness of legal test application
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of legal test by focusing on 'serious efforts' instead of 'adequate protection'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Walvis Bay, possibility of internal relocation
Legal_Framework: Refugee law, principles of state protection, domestic asylum procedures
Evidence_Type: Country condition evidence, legal argument on state protection standards
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remitted to differently constituted panel
Authority: Administrative tribunal (the Board), subject to judicial review by court

Legal_Issue: Whether the risk faced by applicants was generalized or specific
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' testimony accepted as credible
Evidence_Type: Testimony, incident of mistaken identity killing, gang threats
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 97
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mara 13 gang in El Salvador
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Specific targeting by gang after reporting theft to police
Evidence_Ignored: Specific threats and incidents following police report
Legal_Standard: Different in degree from general population risk
Application_Factor: Mistaken identity killing, direct gang threats
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration

Crime_Name: Predatory Pricing and Unlawful Interference with Economic Interests
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants' free online exam guides constituted predatory pricing or unlawful interference with the plaintiff's economic interests
Evidence_Assessment: No proof of intent to harm competition or actual causation of plaintiff's losses; multiple factors contributed to sales decline
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to prove predatory pricing or unlawful interference
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff failed to establish causal link between free guides and financial loss
Legal_Rule: Predatory pricing involves selling at unreasonably low prices to eliminate competitors; unlawful interference requires unlawful means, intent to injure, and actual injury
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendants offering free online exams harmed plaintiff's business and violated the Competition Act
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed on merits due to lack of evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of free online exam guides as marketing tools, market conditions, plaintiff's declining sales data
Legal_Framework: Competition law, tort of unlawful interference with economic interests
Defendant_Response: Free guides were promotional tools, not intended to harm competition
Remedy_Requested: Legal action for violation of Competition Act, likely damages or injunction
Outcome: Dismissal of plaintiff's action
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Competition Act relating to predatory pricing; common law on economic torts

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Public Service Appeal Board Decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the second selection process was a new process or a corrective measure; whether the Commission had authority to conduct a new selection process
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act (PSEA), subsections 21(2), 21(3), and section 10
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following dismissal of appeal by the Public Service Appeal Board
Evidence_Assessment: Commission's letter stating the nature of the new competition
Decision_Outcome: Appeal Board's decision upheld; judicial review application dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error by the Appeal Board
Legal_Rule: PSEA allows but does not require corrective measures under subsection 21(3); subsection 21(2) mandates revocation of appointments on successful appeal; merit-based selection under section 10
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Appeal Board in characterizing the second selection process as entirely new rather than a corrective measure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commission's letter directing a new competition with updated qualifications
Defendant_Response: Commission acted within its authority under PSEA to direct a new selection process
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Appeal Board decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; no costs awarded

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Commission's decision set aside
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper assessment of bona fide occupational requirements
Legal_Framework: Grismer test for bona fide occupational requirements
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted
Case remanded for re-investigation
Credibility: Supported by evidence of accommodation needs post-disclosure
Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (duty to accommodate)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient due to flawed Commission analysis
